Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Last Interglacial Earth System: Testing Transient Climate and Ice-sheet Simulations with a Proxy-data Network
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project's goal is to conduct high-resolution synchronously coupled transient simulations of the last interglacial period (LIG) using a coupled ocean-atmosphere-ice sheet model (Community Earth System Model) in order to provide a consistent physical framework to investigate the mechanisms behind the higher sea level and the potential ~2 degrees Celsius atmospheric warming during the LIG. With both transient and sensitivity simulations of the LIG, the research team aims to systematically investigate the response of climate and the Greenland ice sheet to variations in Earth's orbital configuration, greenhouse gas concentrations, meridional ocean heat transport associated with the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC), and vegetation feedbacks.

By comparing these simulations of the LIG with proxy data from published studies and a new data compilation that captures temporal and spatial temperature variability, the researchers plan to address the following fundamental questions about the LIG: 1) What climate feedbacks are responsible for the up to ~2 degree Celsius reconstructed warming during the LIG with respect to the pre-industrial period; 2) How much did the Greenland Ice Sheet (GrIS) contribute to global sea level rise above present day during the LIG; and 3) How well can the coupled ocean atmosphere-ice sheet model simulate abrupt climate change during major climate transitions, such as the last glacial inception.

This project supports an early career scientist, developing high-resolution climate model output that could serve the wider science community, and engagement of the broader civil society in science-based education outreach

POR.DRECONTENT:
We completed the first reconstruction of global sea surface temperature (SST) during the last interglaciation (LIG). We constrain peak LIG SSTs to be ~0.5±0.3°C higher relative to the 1870-1889 mean, or the same within error (~0.1±0.3°C) as the 1995-2014 mean. Contrary to previous reconstructions, this peak SST warming is no higher than during peak SSTs during the present interglaciation. Warming relative to present occurred in the high latitudes, although the extratropical Northern and Southern Hemispheres had different temperature histories early in the LIG, particularly in the Atlantic basin. This result is consistent with a bipolar seesaw response to freshwater forcing from remnant Northern Hemisphere ice sheets.

We also completed the first transient global climate simulation of penultimate deglaciation (Termination II, or T-II), the LIG, and the last glacial inception, which spans the periods between 140,000 years ago and 115,000 years ago. This 25,000-year transient simulation used a fully coupled atmosphere-ocean general circulation model from the Penultimate Glacial Maximum (PGM) 140 ka through the LIG to 115 ka forced by insolation, greenhouse gases, ice sheets, and freshwater. This simulation provides the physical framework for testing the different mechanisms about the higher temperature and sea level during the LIG and abrupt climate changes during the last glacial inception. We also completed the first simulations with ice sheet models forced by the climate from our transient simulation to assess the impact on mass loss from Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets, and then used a sea-level model to predict how this mass loss would be recorded at far-field sites with records of relative sea level.

Our major findings from this modeling work are the following. (1) Greater subsurface warming induced by the longer duration of reduced Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation during the penultimate deglaciation can explain the more-rapid sea-level rise than during the last deglaciation. (2) This greater forcing also contributed to excess loss from the Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets during the LIG, causing global mean sea level to rise at least 4 m above modern. (3) When accounting for the combined influences of penultimate and last-interglacial deglaciation on glacial isostatic adjustment, this excess loss of polar ice during the LIG can explain much of the relative sea level recorded by fossil coral reefs and speleothems at far-field sites.
